But I guess my question, we get $18 million from OTC clearing per quarter, 2% of revenue. And I know there's a lot of future-ization benefits in there that is hard to specify, but I know it's certainly bolstering our improving revenue and volumes. But this OTC business, what's the next catalyst to get? Will we expect to see more trading or some other catalysts to get the contribution, up from this $18 million that right now, we're realizing per quarter?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'll start and ask Sean and Bryan to join if there's anything to add. I think when you're looking at the OTC efforts, and if you remember when we first walked down this path, we said that OTC market is extremely complementary to the core business of
componenttext: Rich, I'll start and ask Sean and Bryan to join if there's anything to add. I think when you're looking at the OTC efforts, and if you remember when we first walked down this path, we said that OTC market is extremely complementary to the core business of CME. We continue to focus on that core. And in particular, how to make the market in which our clients are efficient as they possibly can. So the $18 million, as you point out, belies the fact that there are cross-margining efficiencies. belies effect that there are future-ization opportunities. And it also belies the fact that what I'll call innovation opportunities that exist. So one such innovation has been the liberal swap huge futures, which is the highest of volume traded futures up to this point in time. That innovation will continue. The cross marketing will continue, and education of our clients, which I also have an ongoing cross process. I think taken together, all of these factors will contribute to the growth of the core product. But in addition to the core, you would see a corresponding growth all of this swaps, swaps side. The advent of more liquidity on may help. There may be some DCMs that offer a swap . That might help. But as we have said in the past, many of these swap products are complicated. And the way that they treat now, I think seemingly, at least to us seems to be a rational way to actually trade. The more important thing is once you've done these trades, how can you hold them in the most effective way possible.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sean jumping it. In terms of innovation within the products itself, most recent innovation was Mexican peso interest rate swaps, Mexican peso interest rate swaps, now the third most important currency from a revenue perspective. From CME Grou
componenttext: Yes, this is Sean jumping it. In terms of innovation within the products itself, most recent innovation was Mexican peso interest rate swaps, Mexican peso interest rate swaps, now the third most important currency from a revenue perspective. From CME Group, that is the 18th currency that we have. We will be shortly adding the Brazilian reai currency as well, which will be the -- our 19th currency. And we have the broadest set of currencies relative to any of our competition. If you look at so far this year, we've had 46 billion a day in non-USD currencies, which means I think without question the deep penetration CME Group has ever had in the non-U.S. dollar interest rate derivatives market. So it's allowing us from an ecosystem perspective, while the revenues are low, from an ecosystem perspective to massively penetrate global market in new currencies in a way that we've never done before. And getting back to Gill's point, it's the portfolio margin and the growth in core. So 500 clients that we are carrying swaps for, we're on a continuous basis cross-selling them into the futures. Earlier this year, capital -- capital -- excuse me, associates issued a paper, total cost analysis, looking at interest rate swaps versus futures. And very clearly, interest rate futures came out as the low-cost alternative across the board relative to interest rate swaps. And what's that allowed us to do, as we talked about earlier, is if you look at a couple of years ago, our treasury market futures have 65% penetration of the cash conversion market. That's now running at around 78%. So from a relative perspective, we've been able to grow our treasury futures again on a relative basis from 65% to now 77%, 78%, so 13 percentage points. When you think about the size of our interest rate futures market, that's actually quite a large increase in revenues pace we've seen on the back of the cross-sell to those 500 swap participants.

componenttext: Rich, this is John, just to put a finer point on it. So as we mentioned, the volume that is left has been more the high velocity hedge fund, low charge per ticket kind of volume. So the revenue drop will be lower than the volume drop. And what you'll see is the rate per OTC trade will likely increase due to that customer mix shift.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to sneak one here and kind of high level. We've seen some really good organic revenue growth this year. You guys are bringing the expense guidance here. Does -- at what point do you think perhaps maybe spending a little bit more? Do you thin
componenttext: I just wanted to sneak one here and kind of high level. We've seen some really good organic revenue growth this year. You guys are bringing the expense guidance here. Does -- at what point do you think perhaps maybe spending a little bit more? Do you think the natural constraint there might be around an operating margin well above in the mid-60s? Or how should we think about that longer term if we continue to see this good organic revenue growth against spending levels right now?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Ken, I'll start and I'll ask John to add. Our willingness and ability to spend is almost entirely dictated by the opportunities that we see. And so there is no stop in spending. If there are opportunities that are worthy to invest -- investment,
componenttext: I think, Ken, I'll start and I'll ask John to add. Our willingness and ability to spend is almost entirely dictated by the opportunities that we see. And so there is no stop in spending. If there are opportunities that are worthy to invest -- investment, we have never hesitated to invest and the -- on a going forward basis, will not change that approach.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken. I think when you think about our opportunity set in kind of what we're doing to manage the business, the areas we're focused on in terms of efficiencies, things like whether it's delayering, whether it's our closing the futures pits, whether it
componenttext: Sure, Ken. I think when you think about our opportunity set in kind of what we're doing to manage the business, the areas we're focused on in terms of efficiencies, things like whether it's delayering, whether it's our closing the futures pits, whether it's optimizing our data center infrastructure, looking at how we provision and consume professional services, all of those expense management techniques are not in any way, shape or form impacting our ability to grow the business, so those are not growth inhibitors. And we do look at redirecting some of those savings towards investments in our growth opportunity. So you'll see, like for example, whether it's in growing our business internationally are whether or not dense investing and our OTC business or whether or not it's investing in electrifying our options, those opportunities are being able to be funded somewhat through managing our core infrastructure. So we feel good about that. In terms of our operating margin, there is no artificial constraint around how high our operating margin can go, I mean other than 100% for a longer period of time. I think our -- I think the way we look at it is we're managing -- we're pulling levers that you could pull, which is making sure we're winning the most efficient engine as we can, and we're also using pricing levers and growing our business through interfacing with our customers. So those are -- that's what we're focused on. We're not focused necessarily on how high our margins can expand. Now historically, we've been as high as 65%, and that was several years ago. So that's the way we've been approaching things.

Welcome to the CME Group's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Mr. John Peschier.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes outlining the highlights of the second quarter, and then we'll open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are also on the call and will participate in the
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes outlining the highlights of the second quarter, and then we'll open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are also on the call and will participate in the Q&A session.
Before they begin, I will read the safe harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are available on our website.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Peschier. And thank you for joining us today. We had an impressive second quarter and the diversity of our product offerings was evident in the results achieved. We delivered significant top line growth in transaction fees and market data r
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Peschier. And thank you for joining us today. We had an impressive second quarter and the diversity of our product offerings was evident in the results achieved. We delivered significant top line growth in transaction fees and market data revenue, which, coupled with lower expenses, resulted in a 23% increase in earnings per share. After an industry slowdown in April, our volume finished the quarter with June up 15% compared to the prior June. ADV across all 6 product areas were up in June and 4 of them were up in double-digits. Our commodities portfolio was up 36%, while financial products increased by 12%. 
In terms of Q2 activity, in our commodities portfolio, we saw strong results with ADV up 22% across energy, ags and metal. In ags, we delivered record quarterly volume in corn, soybeans and wheat. The surge in activity was driven by concerns of an El Nino in the equatorial Pacific Ocean, resulting in anticipated increased rain in the U.S. and Brazil, and the potential drought conditions in Australia and Southeast Asia. The resulting price movement, volatility and declining prices has sparked renewed hedging activity in both futures and options.
Energy volumes also performed extremely well in Q2, with ADV up 20%, driven by 32% growth in our crude complex, with 68% of our WTI options now trading electronically on Globex. In June, nat gas results trended well as volume rose 30% and nat gas options were up 37% as our market share also rose. Total energy volume and revenue were each up 20%, double that of our primary competitor.
Within the financial product area, foreign exchange trading growth was significant during the second quarter, rising 42%. FX futures were up 38%, while FX options grew 83%.
Interest rates volumes accelerated during the quarter from $5.1 million per day in April to $7.4 million during the rest of the quarter. Interest rate activity at CME has performed well relative to substitute products that were out there and were up 7%. 
Our penetration of the cash treasury market increased from 77% at the end of Q1 to 78% this quarter. In addition, the total number of large institutional open interest holders in our rates futures business grew to 1,705 at the end of the quarter, which is up 7% from the beginning of the year.
We are particularly pleased with the activity in Eurodollar options ahead of a potential Fed move. Eurodollar options on Globex were up 60% to 148,000 contracts per day during the quarter and up 84% in June. Importantly, we have seen the percentage of Eurodollar options traded electronically move from 12% in Q2 last year to 18% this year and up to 22% in July. The biggest driver has been a surge in activity coming from European traders. In addition, we had a record number of weekly treasury options traded in June at 140,000 ADV. July remains extremely strong as well. 
Lastly, Fed funds futures have become popular again for the first time since the credit crisis. Volume has tripled from last year so far in 2015. ADV is above 60,000 contracts compared to 20,000 last year.
During the quarter, our revenue and interest rate swap carrying grew by 36%, while credit swaps swap clearing was up 11% to total approximately $18 million. We have seen a slowdown of activity in swaps in July due to the basis spread between CME and LCH. The basis has stabilized and tightened recently. The OTC swaps revenue trajectory for July looked similar to April based on the client mix, as the decreases we have seen are mainly in lower-priced OIS trades coming from large hedge fund clients. On the flip side, we have seen a record number of dealer-to-dealer trades, which is encouraging.
We continue to look at opportunities to address challenges our customers are facing. There has been a decline in cash market liquidity in the government securities market due in part to more stringent capital, leverage and liquidity standards for banks and heightened regulatory scrutiny, and this may have contributed to the increased client use of the treasury futures product. 
We also had a webinar this Tuesday with a large number of market participants to discuss the concept of filling the 15-year gap between the 6.5-year point tracked by our 10-year treasury contracts and the 21.5-year point tracked by our 30-year long bond.
Turning to our global business. Work by our staff and volume from outside of the U.S. continues to be impressive. Our Q2 electronic trading volume out of Asia jumped 22% from the second quarter last year, with the highest volume growth in our FX and equity product areas. Europe was up 10%, with ag products up 50% and FX was also strong. North America and Latin America were each up 6%. Electronic volume from outside the U.S. was up 12% and revenue was up 19%.
Turning to growth in our robust options market. We continue to invest in system enhancements, new products and investor education which is driving significant usage of our diverse suite of options products. Q2 ADV rose 13% to 2.6 million contracts, with electronic volumes up 29% compared to the prior year. In July, option volumes remained extremely strong. 
Overall, 53% of our options traded electronically in June, up from 50% in 2014. As I mentioned on the financial side, we have seen strong growth in Eurodollar options, weekly treasury options and also FX options.
On the commodities portfolio, we are seeing strength in WTI options and agricultural products, with July running at peak levels in these commodities. I think that suggests that market participants are anticipating more volatility ahead. After some enhanced volatility in early July with the situation in Greece and large movements in the Chinese equities market, activity has returned to the normal summer vacation mode.  However, the options positioning suggests that market participants are looking ahead. 
So overall, we continue to execute on our strategy to deliver growth in a highly efficient rate throughout the organization.
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gill. And good morning, everyone. I'm pleased with our results this quarter. We drove double-digit organic revenue growth while our expenses decreased, driving significant operating leverage and EPS growth. Q2 revenue was up 12%, which follows
componenttext:
Thank you, Gill. And good morning, everyone. I'm pleased with our results this quarter. We drove double-digit organic revenue growth while our expenses decreased, driving significant operating leverage and EPS growth. Q2 revenue was up 12%, which follows the 8% revenue growth we delivered in Q1. Volume in the second quarter started slow, but finished exceptionally strong. Our adjusted expenses for the quarter were down 1% from the same quarter last year, driven primarily by decreases in marketing and other costs and professional fees. Our variable costs, license fees and bonus increased due to our improved performance compared to last year. Our operating margins are, again, above 60% with an adjusted operating margin of 60.5%, which improved from 55% a year ago. Finally, our adjusted EPS grew 23% during the quarter, up from 18% growth in Q1.
I'll start with some revenue details. The rate per contract for Q1 was $0.777, up from $0.753 last quarter. The largest impact was driven by a favorable shift in product mix, with record agricultural commodities propelling the RPC higher. The other positives include a larger proportion from higher paying nonmembers in several product areas, lower volume tier impact and lastly, our pricing change that went into effect in February.
OTC swaps revenue totaled $18 million for the quarter, up 35% versus $13 million last year. During the second quarter, we captured $139 per IRS clear trade, an increase from the $130 range which we have been averaging. We cleared approximately 1,950 trades per day in Q2, up 38% from a year ago.
Market data revenue of $103 million was up 15% versus Q2 last year, driven primarily by the elimination of our fee waiver program, which we have discussed the last few quarters. Fortunately, we saw better than expected screen counts for both grandfathered and full-paying customers in the second quarter. We will continue to monitor the impacts from the fee changes, and we currently anticipate about $100 million per quarter of market data revenue for the remainder of 2015 based on potential attrition from here.
Adjusted operating expenses in Q2 were $324 million, down $3.4 million from Q2 last year. We remain extremely focused on driving efficiencies throughout the organization and eliminating redundancy to improve agility in customer and market responsiveness. At the end of Q2, we had 2,650 employees, down 20 from the end of Q1 and down 30 from the beginning of the year. In July, we eliminated an additional 60 lower-level positions related to the closure of most of our futures bids in Chicago and New York.
Within the compensation line, our base and benefits were down 2% from last year and down 1% from last quarter. The stock-based compensation increased approximately $5 million sequentially. This was driven almost entirely by the performance share component of our equity program, which is based on total shareholder return relative to the S&P 500 and cash earnings generation during the 3-year period from 2013 through 2015.  Based on the factor, we're tracking well above the 75th percentile of the S&P 500 in total shareholder return as well as being ahead of our cash earnings target. We expect to reach the maximum payout and we accounted for it this quarter. Our compensation ratio for the first half of the year is running at an industry-leading 16.5%, down from 17.1% in 2014 and 17.4% in 2013.
Turning to taxes. The effective rate for the quarter was 36.6%. I expect the second half of the year to come in around 37%.
And now to the balance sheet. At the end of the quarter and after refinancing our debt, which we covered last quarter, we had $1.33 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities. That is approximately $630 million above our $700 million minimum cash target.
During the second quarter, capital expenditures, net of leasehold improvement allowance, just totaled $28 million, and we are at $55 million for the year-to-date. We expect full year 2015 CapEx to come in at $140 million, similar to last year and below our original guidance of $150 million.
For the full year, we expect adjusted expenses to be $10 million lower than we had previously guided to at $1.3 billion, down about 1% from last year despite our current double-digit revenue growth.
In summary, the second quarter of 2015 once again demonstrated the power of the CME Group business model. Broad-based volume growth and our disciplined expense management drove adjusted EPS of more than 20%. The entire management team continues to focus on driving earnings growth as we come out of this cycle and returning the maximum amount of capital to our shareholders. In the last few months, we have closed the majority of our futures bids, reduced overall headcount, consolidated data centers and reduced branding-related costs.
With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. [Operator Instructions]

So maybe, could you give us further details on what really is happening here? I do believe Gill mentioned that the spread has narrowed. I think our calculations for that the spread narrowed from about 2 basis points to somewhere in the 1.4 basis point range for a 30-year product. So it has narrowed, but it's still reasonably wide. I guess, the last part is what is the outlook there? And does business start to come back to CME?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Sean Tully, I'm responsible for financials, jumping in. In terms of the basis itself, in early May, the basis did jump. So in the 10-year sector, it went from around 0.25 basis point out to a peak of 2.35 basis points. Once the basis jumped, once
componenttext:
This is Sean Tully, I'm responsible for financials, jumping in. In terms of the basis itself, in early May, the basis did jump. So in the 10-year sector, it went from around 0.25 basis point out to a peak of 2.35 basis points. Once the basis jumped, once it widened, CME Group did make the decision to issue its own specific CME curve for interest rate swaps. Yes, obviously, that's very prudent from a risk management perspective, but also adds massive transparency to the marketplace. We announced that on the -- on May 13. June 8, we implemented the CME-specific curve, and since then, the basis has stabilized dramatically. So since June 8, the average standard deviation on a daily basis is less than five hundredths of a basis point, so really completely de minimis. If you look at the last week or so, the entire range of that spread has been 1/10 of a basis point in the 10-year trading between 0.9 of a basis points and 1.0 basis points. What that means is that while the volatility was high during early May since we've added transparency, since we've added a CME-specific curve, the market has completely stabilized. 
And in terms of interest rate swaps, if you're an active trader, the level of which you get in relative to, let's say, a competitor is not nearly as important as the level you get in versus the level you get out. So what matters is the stability of the spread, and we've seen that. 
In addition to that, with the fluidity of the spread, but also with the increased interest in this, we have seen record volumes in dealer-to-dealer trading at CME Group. So we now have 25 dealers trading -- actively trading on that basis. And again, it's at a very tight level. The bid offer spread in the interdealer market is, again, around 5/100s of a basis point. If you think about that relative to outright level of rates, that is 100th, literally 100th the volatility of the level of outright rates since June 8. 
In addition to seeing the increased dealer-to-dealer activity, since May 1, we've seen 18 new clients. So we've had 18 new clients that had never cleared with CME Group previously jump into the marketplace and to begin to clear swaps here. Many folks wanted to take advantage of the higher rates that they could get at our platform. In addition to that, with the higher rate for certain folks, in particular large issuers of U.S. dollar debt, this may be seen as an advantage. Hence, we've also seen an increased interest on folks becoming new clearing members at CME Group, in particular, issuers of debt.

componenttext: I just wanted to ask if you guys could provide any color on the open interest trends we're seeing? We've seen -- I mean, year-over-year growth has been slowing since April. In July, it's trending down on a year-over-year perspective, particularly kind of looking like at it like the rate open interest levels are kind of raising some eyebrows, just given we're pretty close to a potential said fed move in September, December. So any color there would be greatly appreciated.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to start, and I'm going to ask both Derek and Sean to comment on the individual portfolios. I think on the whole, if you look at the growth of open interest, particularly in relation to where we ended the year last year, it's pretty posi
componenttext:
Sure. I'm going to start, and I'm going to ask both Derek and Sean to comment on the individual portfolios. 
I think on the whole, if you look at the growth of open interest, particularly in relation to where we ended the year last year, it's pretty positive. Well, I think there's a small dip in the energy portfolio, and I stress small. But if you're looking across the rest of the portfolio that we have where open interest is concerned, where rates and equity and commodities and alternatives are seeing double-digit growth in open interest, foreign exchange open interest, which, as we articulated last year, which was very high at the end of last year, is still even up 7%. And for the metals portfolio, it is up 2%. 
With that, I'm going to pass it over to both Sean and Derek to comment about their individual portfolios.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Derek. On the energy side, where I'll probably focus a little bit more, the drop-off in the open interest has really been the power side. And not so much as the CME story, that's an industry story. So there's no real surprise there. That's a mar
componenttext: Yes, it's Derek. On the energy side, where I'll probably focus a little bit more, the drop-off in the open interest has really been the power side. And not so much as the CME story, that's an industry story. So there's no real surprise there. That's a market segment that's going under some significant change right now. We're doing extremely well on nat gas and WTI. I mean, you've seen the volume growth, in particular in the options side as well, with the options volume up in TI close to 57%. When you look at our competitor on the Brent side, they're up about 10%. So the outperformance on the volume side being matched by the open interest growth side there.

componenttext: In terms of financials, interest rates, since you're end up 10% in terms of open interest, equities up 20% and foreign exchange up 7% after, as Gill said, very strong growth last year. We're seeing increasing uncertainty with the interest rate market [indiscernible] of potential fed rate hikes later this year or early next year. So continues to be strong growth.

componenttext:
I think, Rich, if you have the asset classes such as the ones that we have where you have benchmarks across the board, and I think the -- a very specific emphasis for us was to grow our client base, not just here, but around the world. And in particular, the globalization efforts that we have marked upon has been really successful. We have seen a growth in our client accounts. We are overseeing on the OTC side. I think Sean gave us a very thorough analysis of the growth on the OTC side. Of particular interest to us and what we are encouraged by the growth of the large open interest holders in some of the key asset classes that we have. 
I'm going to ask Bryan if he has anything to add here in terms of the globalization efforts for us.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, really the diversity of the product and asset classes that we represent has played extremely well in our international growth model. And as a result, we've seen double-digit growth occurring across the asset classes, both throughout Asia as w
componenttext: Yes, I mean, really the diversity of the product and asset classes that we represent has played extremely well in our international growth model. And as a result, we've seen double-digit growth occurring across the asset classes, both throughout Asia as well as within the EMEA sector. I think it's a demonstration of a very methodical and focused program where we're able to strategically locate our employees throughout the globe and be able to identify opportunities for further penetration and go after those customers. So part of the thing that we measure is also new client acquisition that we bring into the marketplace, and we're pretty pleased with the growth trajectory in that and to a -- particularly for this past quarter.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Rich, just to add one last thing, and I'll ask Mr. Sammann to talk a little bit about that, is the growth in the electronification of options for us. And options, in general actually because -- by the way, on the cusp of change, but it's uncertain wit
componenttext: And Rich, just to add one last thing, and I'll ask Mr. Sammann to talk a little bit about that, is the growth in the electronification of options for us. And options, in general actually because -- by the way, on the cusp of change, but it's uncertain with respect to both the timing and the scope and the scale of that change. We're seeing remarkable activity here.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gill. I think to the extent that the overall franchise has grown significantly over the course of the year, we actually look at July, even -- on a going-forward basis, our July options volumes on average are up 30% across the board. Every single asse
componenttext:
Yes, Gill. I think to the extent that the overall franchise has grown significantly over the course of the year, we actually look at July, even -- on a going-forward basis, our July options volumes on average are up 30% across the board. Every single asset class is up above between 24% and 30%. 
Specifically on electronification side, we're continuing to see trends that you've heard us talk about quarter-on-quarter. Our investments in education, in analytics, in technology is allowing us to not only continue to grow our business, but all the electronic -- all the growth is coming electronically right now. And so when you look at the aggregate portfolio, now 53% of our business and options trades electronically, and all that increase in ADV growth quarter-on-quarter is all coming on Globex. Gill briefly mentioned that the consistent growth in Eurodollar electronification from 12% last year to 18%, July is 23%. 
Other notable events, gold options, for example, tripled -- or doubled in volume last week with a new low in gold. And the options volume went from basically 60% electronic to 80% electronic. So what we're seeing is in high volume days, in spiking volume days, that growth is outpacing itself on the electronic side. So a big area of investment in growth, and I think the numbers are bearing that out.

componenttext: Not much here, so maybe you can -- well, one of the items that you might give an update on is the whole equivalency debate between U.S. and Europe, the 1-day gross, 2-day net. One thing that somebody mentioned I talked to the other day was that they might just go to the least common denominator, which will be 2-day gross. I don't know if you've heard that. But interested in what that would mean to your business because that sounds, obviously, a pretty onerous solution.

It's clear to us that his orientation is to be fair and also to get the best outcome for global investors here. And Terry just walked in a second...

componenttext: Equivalents.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we testified yesterday on the G20 commitments. Equivalents, obviously, was something that I raised in there. And you can imagine people saying they want to have parity. I did reference to the Congress and others that we were prepared to give parity by
componenttext: So we testified yesterday on the G20 commitments. Equivalents, obviously, was something that I raised in there. And you can imagine people saying they want to have parity. I did reference to the Congress and others that we were prepared to give parity by saying that we would take the higher of, whether it was -- whatever the regime was, and others still balked at that. So we -- it's clearly a competitive issue. Chairman Massad recognizes it's a competitive issue. And I don't see him balking away from what we have here in the United States as the stronger regime being 1-day gross for client and 1-day net for house. So I think we're in one of those situations where we're going to have to wait and see how the Chairman reacts. I met with him again yesterday while in D.C. And so I do believe that equivalents will get done. And it will done probably, I would hope sometime in September, October time period, but we'll have to wait and see. But I do believe that everybody in this country feels fairly strongly that our regime is the best regime. And we were going to have a standard global regime in years to come, hopefully, and we won't have to go through this exercise like we're going through right now.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Terry, sorry, you probably missed that part of my question. But I suggested like -- that some people have said 2-day gross could be the one solution. Do you think that's on the table? And it could impact your business? Or do you think that's a nonstar
componenttext: And Terry, sorry, you probably missed that part of my question. But I suggested like -- that some people have said 2-day gross could be the one solution. Do you think that's on the table? And it could impact your business? Or do you think that's a nonstarter?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's a nonstarter. I don't think it's on the table. I've heard nobody even reference it. I've heard nobody in our own governments reference it. They already realize that 1-day gross is collecting a higher margin on the client side to roughly over
componenttext: I think it's a nonstarter. I don't think it's on the table. I've heard nobody even reference it. I've heard nobody in our own governments reference it. They already realize that 1-day gross is collecting a higher margin on the client side to roughly over $38 billion to $40 billion higher than 2-day net. So I think they feel that that's plenty of coverage going forward. And I have not heard anybody in this country introduce or discuss 2-day gross.

I'm wondering if you could just kind of give some stats around what's happened thus far and kind of how conservative your outlook is and kind of what some of those assumptions are going forward for how you're thinking about attrition?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Dan. We are very happy with our excellent market data results. In the first quarter, we only had 2 billing periods and screen counts. So we accrued at an -- an anticipated level of higher attrition than we are currently experiencing. So we made
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Dan. We are very happy with our excellent market data results. In the first quarter, we only had 2 billing periods and screen counts. So we accrued at an -- an anticipated level of higher attrition than we are currently experiencing. So we made an adjustment this quarter to reflect better than expected level of screens. So we're going to continue to monitor the impacts of the pricing changes closely. So you -- we currently expect the second half of the year to be approximately the same as the first half. 
We're not giving out any specific statistics around the number of screens, but what I can tell you is that they've been holding relatively flat. So we're pretty comfortable at the $100 million per quarter level. I'll just ask Bryan to kind of chime in, in terms of what he's hearing from the customers as it relates to market data.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just say we got out there well in advance of the changes that were taking effect over the course of the past 12 months. The client base was well informed about our elimination of the waiver. We've worked very closely with the community in terms of
componenttext: I would just say we got out there well in advance of the changes that were taking effect over the course of the past 12 months. The client base was well informed about our elimination of the waiver. We've worked very closely with the community in terms of making some adjustments in the reporting of screens and whatnot. Categorization of the type of trader, we made some modifications there. So I think the marketplace, one, recognizes the value associated with market data, understands that we are going to continue to charge for it. And as we continue to enhance the product itself, there's value associated with it. And the market is responding effectively in terms of the changes that we've put in incrementally until we get to the ultimate full paying in end of that waiver period of next year.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question. I think it looked like on the non-op side, you guys -- you maybe sold some shares on the BM&F side. So I just wanted to get an update on the strategic relationship. And then, maybe just broader, given the global landscape, just how you gu
componenttext: Just a question. I think it looked like on the non-op side, you guys -- you maybe sold some shares on the BM&F side. So I just wanted to get an update on the strategic relationship. And then, maybe just broader, given the global landscape, just how you guys are thinking about the longer term in terms of either consolidation or relationships and how you guys are positioned for that?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. This is John, Mike. We sold approximately 14.3 million BM&F shares. So we did about $58 million in proceeds from those sales. We still hold 98 million shares or approximately 5.4% of BVMF. We did this for tax planning purposes, so we're likely
componenttext:
Sure, yes. This is John, Mike. We sold approximately 14.3 million BM&F shares. So we did about $58 million in proceeds from those sales. We still hold 98 million shares or approximately 5.4% of BVMF. We did this for tax planning purposes, so we're likely to do some more. It's really strictly for tax planning. 
I think the relationship with BVMF is extremely strong. It's one of our key relationships around the globe. We work with them across multiple projects, whether it's on the technology side, whether it's on the product side or on the strategic side. So the relationship is really good. 
We are -- globalization is a very key part of our overall strategy. One of the components of that globalization, along with putting customer-facing people around the world, is our relationships with key country champions in each of the locales. We recently signed an MOU with India, and I'll ask Derek to comment on that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you probably saw, we've put a press release out last week where we executed an MOU with MCX, the Multi Commodities Exchange, which is the largest Indian commodities exchange. They have a 85% market share in the commodities space. And what we've co
componenttext:
Yes. As you probably saw, we've put a press release out last week where we executed an MOU with MCX, the Multi Commodities Exchange, which is the largest Indian commodities exchange. They have a 85% market share in the commodities space. And what we've committed to work with them is we've got a 10-year commercial relationship with them by which they license our Henry Hub and WTI settlement prices, and they trade futures on the back of that that's settled to our prices. We wanted to expand that, and given the pace of change from a regulatory perspective in India, with the regulators rolling up under one single umbrella under SEBI, we wanted very much to both influence where we can, but also get closer to a strategic partner. So we've launched the commitment, started a number of work streams, one of which is to launch a joint study looking into the feasibility of setting up exchange and clearing operations in the IFSC, International Financial Service Center, in India in the state of Gujarat. 
So it's -- it looks like an interesting opportunity. India is very much opening under the Modi government, and to the point that John maybe thought about country champions. MCX is certainly the leading commodities exchange, which makes sense to match up and work closely with us as the global leader in the commodities side here.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ms. Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ms. Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So given the success you guys were having in electrifying Eurodollar options and just the options complex as a whole, any updates on the potential shutdowns of trading pits? And I guess, how that could potentially play into your expense initiatives toward
componenttext: So given the success you guys were having in electrifying Eurodollar options and just the options complex as a whole, any updates on the potential shutdowns of trading pits? And I guess, how that could potentially play into your expense initiatives towards the end of the year and beyond?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alex. This is John. As we indicated previously, when we closed down the futures pits, we were able to unlock about $10 million in annual cost savings. We anticipate running the entire floors, both in Chicago and in New York. The cost is approximatel
componenttext:
Sure, Alex. This is John. As we indicated previously, when we closed down the futures pits, we were able to unlock about $10 million in annual cost savings. We anticipate running the entire floors, both in Chicago and in New York. The cost is approximately $50 million a year, so $40 million remaining for the open pits. 
What's key for us is that we don't force the markets to move -- the markets will move when and if they are -- find liquidity and better execution on the box. So we want to manage that carefully. So when you take a look, several of our pits are now approaching the 80%, 90% electronic phase. So it is something that we look, but we want them -- the market to determine it. 
I'll turn it over to Derek who manages our options business.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's right. And as you've heard us talk about, our continued investment in the technology side is to enable this sort of complex spread trading that used to only be available on the floor. We're making that increasingly available with our s
componenttext:
Yes, I think that's right. And as you've heard us talk about, our continued investment in the technology side is to enable this sort of complex spread trading that used to only be available on the floor. We're making that increasingly available with our solutions like CME Direct and adding analytics and capabilities to our electronic trading capability. 
So as John said, the market will find its place of liquidity. Increasingly, in times of high volume and high volatility, that growth has come in electronically. So we'll let that run its course.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The central theme here, Alex, has not changed from the time that we did mutualize. We said and our clients said it's time to shut the pit, we would shut our pit. The fact that we have done really well electronically is fantastic for us. It's a client choi
componenttext: The central theme here, Alex, has not changed from the time that we did mutualize. We said and our clients said it's time to shut the pit, we would shut our pit. The fact that we have done really well electronically is fantastic for us. It's a client choice issue. The fact that some volumes still remains in the pits is an indicator to us that the -- that at -- it's an indicator to us that although the trend is very positive, the pits remain viable for the options.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Gill, if I might just add. I don't want to undermine the fact that how important liquidity is on strategy-type transactions. Options are strategy-type transactions. Futures lend themselves more to trading electronically. Some of our products do lend t
componenttext: And Gill, if I might just add. I don't want to undermine the fact that how important liquidity is on strategy-type transactions. Options are strategy-type transactions. Futures lend themselves more to trading electronically. Some of our products do lend themselves in trading electronically on the options side, others do not at this point in time -- some of our biggest products for that fact. And the last thing we want to do is to try to move a lever to move a business and hurt that business. So I think it's critically important that we continue to manage it the way we've been doing it all along. So again, I think you cannot dismiss the value of liquidity, market-making capabilities and abilities the way we have them on options. They are different from futures.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to add to what Terry said, we generate well in excess of $100 million per year out of the options pits themselves.
componenttext: And just to add to what Terry said, we generate well in excess of $100 million per year out of the options pits themselves.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe you can dive a little bit deeper into the energy complex, maybe just to give us an update on how some of the initiatives in Brent are going in terms of getting more commercial volume across your energy complex. And then, any thoughts on the new NASD
componenttext: Maybe you can dive a little bit deeper into the energy complex, maybe just to give us an update on how some of the initiatives in Brent are going in terms of getting more commercial volume across your energy complex. And then, any thoughts on the new NASDAQ's NFX platform coming into play here? Could it potentially be even a positive from the usage of market makers arbitraging volumes against your complex?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Brian. It's Derek here. Brent continues to move along. We have about a 12% market share in that market. And it's important not only as you work for Brent trading in it of itself, but the spreads back into TI. So we're happy with that pace. We
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Brian. It's Derek here. Brent continues to move along. We have about a 12% market share in that market. And it's important not only as you work for Brent trading in it of itself, but the spreads back into TI. So we're happy with that pace. We have no plans with changing, if any, at this point. We're making steady progress and we've actually had some wins with some smaller commercials jump onboard as well. So we're continuing to drive that and expand the ecosystem of participants there. 
Relative to the NFX move when they opened on Friday, we've seen these entrants in other asset classes over time, whether it was ELX or NYPC or other efforts to come in, in sort of onshore [indiscernible] you say the products. 
As we talked about in the last call, in the absence of product differentiation, the capital efficiency story, depth of liquidity, diversity of products, or client diversification, outside of that, just want you to meet to [ph] in the existing products, I think is a challenging value prop. I think if you look at the depth of our market and the expanse of our WTI franchise right now, we're comfortable with the position. We absolutely welcome competition. And we'll let you guys decide how successful you think they're going to be.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think it could actually improve your TI volumes, if there's increasing arbitrage activity from the market makers?
componenttext: And do you think it could actually improve your TI volumes, if there's increasing arbitrage activity from the market makers?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's interesting. We actually saw that happen in both NYPC and ELX when there was sort of a risk [indiscernible] where people would just put the risk on here and there. Frankly, unless it's real customer volume and real open interest that grows there, yes
componenttext: It's interesting. We actually saw that happen in both NYPC and ELX when there was sort of a risk [indiscernible] where people would just put the risk on here and there. Frankly, unless it's real customer volume and real open interest that grows there, yes, we'll benefit, but it won't necessarily be to the benefit of it. It's just market maker to market maker activity on that side. So if it's true to form for every previous attack, yes, we'll see a small bump in our side. You'll likely see a one-for-one. There no shifts going on, but you'll likely see increase that are matched one-for-one increase here.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris of Wells Fargo.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So a question on your volume growth outside the U.S. We look at these numbers and they're clearly very impressive. One of the things that we struggle with is how large your addressable market really is outside the U.S. And so just wondering if you guys ha
componenttext: So a question on your volume growth outside the U.S. We look at these numbers and they're clearly very impressive. One of the things that we struggle with is how large your addressable market really is outside the U.S. And so just wondering if you guys have done any work on that, and maybe wanting to get your comment on how penetrated you think you are at this point relative to the global opportunity.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, I will start and ask Bryan to add if he is -- he would choose to. If you look at growth outside of the U.S., I think from your perspective and you're trying to see what the addressable market is, look at the top 10 exchanges that exist now, and the
componenttext:
Chris, I will start and ask Bryan to add if he is -- he would choose to. If you look at growth outside of the U.S., I think from your perspective and you're trying to see what the addressable market is, look at the top 10 exchanges that exist now, and then dial it up back 10 years and look at the top 10 exchanges then. What you will see is a lot of growth, a lot of activity coming from, in particular, the Chinese exchanges in the various part of the globe, the Hong Kong exchange whose derivatives volumes have traditionally been very small, is not a focus for us. But the client base, the M&As from Hong Kong is because they also have touch points into China. So that would be a very simple broad-based look at what the so-called addressable market is outside of the U.S. 
And another way to think about it is that the portion of the global trade volume that the CME Group companies had several years ago was just the portion of the global trade volume that they have now. 
And then, the third dimension that I would use is the fixed asset classes and the portfolio that we have and the benchmark that we have within each of those -- all of those asset classes have a global appeal. And so they, in that sense, make the job of selling these products around the world very easy for us relative to other exchanges. 
These factors, in total, actually are driving the growth that you are seeing, where the quality of the markets around the clock, the quality of the products, global benchmarks and the reach of these products are past 200 countries around the world. 
Bryan, anything to add?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, you covered it.
componenttext: No, you covered it.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Does that make sense?
componenttext: Does that make sense?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It does.
componenttext: It does.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kyle Voigt of KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kyle Voigt of KBW.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, if you could just touch on another regulatory issue on position, one that's in particular. Because there was a CFTC advisory committee meeting yesterday on the topic. And it seems like within the commission, there's an openness to having exchange
componenttext: I guess, if you could just touch on another regulatory issue on position, one that's in particular. Because there was a CFTC advisory committee meeting yesterday on the topic. And it seems like within the commission, there's an openness to having exchanges involved in implementation and oversight of the position limits. So I guess, my question would really be twofold. So first, what are the risks to the commodities market today that you see under the current proposed position limits and the enumerated bona fide hedging assumptions? And then secondly, what is the feedback that you've gotten from the commission on potentially being a part of the oversight and in limitation of the position limits and hedging exemptions?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. And I actually serve on the Energy Markets Advisory Committee, and so I participated in that discussion yesterday. And our message to the commission has been twofold. I mean, one, we've had a very strong program in place for many, many year
componenttext: This is Bryan. And I actually serve on the Energy Markets Advisory Committee, and so I participated in that discussion yesterday. And our message to the commission has been twofold. I mean, one, we've had a very strong program in place for many, many years that has been very effective, looking at our markets, the efficiency of those markets, focusing on spot month limits, which is where the criticality of market convergence takes effect. We've continued spreading that message and working with the community and working very closely with the commission. I'm looking at what's been proposed today, how it would be very restrictive in the context and impactful, we believe, to the liquidity and performance of these markets if the current proposed language for hedge exemptions were to become finalized. We believe that the efforts that have been undertaken by the community, in conjunction with market participants, has helped the commission understand and appreciate the impacts of the proposed rulemaking that's out there today. And we're very hopeful for a more balanced and pragmatic outcome with position limits and hedge exemptions. Terry?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just add to what Bryan said because I did put this in my testimony also yesterday to make certain that we cannot have a position limits regime that's different than the rest of the world that make the U.S. anticompetitive because one of the gr
componenttext:
Yes. Let me just add to what Bryan said because I did put this in my testimony also yesterday to make certain that we cannot have a position limits regime that's different than the rest of the world that make the U.S. anticompetitive because one of the great benefits we have is discovering price in this country. 
Yesterday at Bryan's meeting, a question came up. And then, I heard this through one of the staff that as a public company, are we the right person to be setting position limits? Well, the answer to that question is we are absolutely the right company to be setting the position limits because we have the most at risk on the credibility by marketplace more than anybody else. So we are -- we have the expertise to do it, as Bryan has outlined. And of course, the credibility issue is what we're all about. And if we don't have a credible market, we don't have a credible institution. So we have the most incentive to make to make sure that these position limits are set properly and these markets are policed correctly.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from the line of Mr. Rich Repetto of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our last question comes from the line of Mr. Rich Repetto of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up and -- Gill and Bryan, I know -- or Sean, when you went through the whole -- the basis point spread changes. But I guess, my question, we're getting $18 million from OTC clearing per quarter, 2% of your revenue. And I know there's
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up and -- Gill and Bryan, I know -- or Sean, when you went through the whole -- the basis point spread changes. But I guess, my question, we're getting $18 million from OTC clearing per quarter, 2% of your revenue. And I know there's a lot of future-ization benefits in there that is hard to specify, but it's certainly bolstering or improving revenue and volumes. But this OTC business, what's the next catalyst to get -- will we expect to see more SEF trading or some other catalysts to get the contribution up from this $18 million that, right now, we're realizing per quarter?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, I'll start, and then I'll ask Sean and Bryan to join if there's anything to add. I think if you're looking at the OTC efforts, and if you remember when we first walked down this path, we said that the OTC market was extremely complementary to the co
componenttext:
Rich, I'll start, and then I'll ask Sean and Bryan to join if there's anything to add. I think if you're looking at the OTC efforts, and if you remember when we first walked down this path, we said that the OTC market was extremely complementary to the core business of CME. We continue to focus on that core. And in particular, how to make the market in which we offer our clients as efficient as we possibly can. So the $18 million, as you pointed out, belies the fact that there are cross margin efficiencies. It belies effect that there are future-ization opportunities. And it also belies the fact that there are what I would call innovation opportunities that exist. So one such innovation has been the deliverable swap, huge futures, which is the highest of volume traded futures up to this point in time. That innovation will continue. The cross margining will continue. And the education of our clients is also an ongoing process. 
I think, taken together, all of these factors will contribute to the growth of not just the core product, but in addition to the core, you would see a corresponding growth on the swaps side. 
The SEF -- the advent of more liquidity on SEF may help. There may be some DCMs that will offer a swap trading, that might help. But as we have said in the past, many of these swap products are complicated. And the way that they trade now, I think seemingly, at least to us, seems to be a rational way to actually trade. The more important thing is once you've done these trades, how can you hold them in the most efficient way possible.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sean jumping in. In terms of innovation within the products itself, most recent innovation was Mexican peso interest rate swaps. Mexican peso interest rate swaps, now the third most important currency from a revenue perspective. For CME Group
componenttext:
Yes, this is Sean jumping in. In terms of innovation within the products itself, most recent innovation was Mexican peso interest rate swaps. Mexican peso interest rate swaps, now the third most important currency from a revenue perspective. For CME Group, that is the 18th currency that we have. We will be shortly adding the Brazilian real currency as well, which will be a -- our 19th currency. And we have the broadest set of currencies relative to any of our competition. 
If you look at so far this year, we've had $46 billion a day in non-USD currencies, so I think it's the -- I think, without question, the deepest penetration CME Group has ever had in the non-U.S. dollar interest rate derivatives market. So it's allowing us, from an ecosystem perspective, while the revenues are low, from an ecosystem perspective, to massively penetrate the global market in new currencies in a way that we have never done before. 
And getting back to Gill's point, it's the portfolio margin and the growth of the core. So 500 clients that we are carrying interest rate swaps for, we're, on a continuous basis, cross-selling them into the futures. Earlier this year, Greenwich Capital -- no, not Greenwich Capital, excuse me -- Greenwich Associates issued a paper of total cost analysis, looking at interest rate swaps versus futures. And very clearly, the interest rate futures came out as the lower cost alternative across the board relative to interest rate swaps. And what that's allowed us to do, as we talked about earlier, is if you look at a couple of years ago, our treasury market futures have a 65% penetration of the cash treasury market, that is now running at around 78%. So from a relative perspective, we've been able to grow our treasury futures, again, on a relative basis, from 65% to now 77%, 78%, so 13 percentage points. When you think about the size of our interest rate futures market, that's actually quite a large increase in revenues that we've seen on the back of the cross-sell to those 500 swap participants.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is John. Just to put a fine point on it. So as we mentioned, the volume that is left has been more of the high velocity hedge fund, low charge per ticket kind of volume. So the revenue drop will be lower than the volume drop. And what you will
componenttext: Rich, this is John. Just to put a fine point on it. So as we mentioned, the volume that is left has been more of the high velocity hedge fund, low charge per ticket kind of volume. So the revenue drop will be lower than the volume drop. And what you will see is the rate per OTC trade will likely increase due to that customer mix shift.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I guess, my point is EBIT was up 50%. We're still talking 3% of revenue. Again, and I acknowledge the portfolio margining and the future-ization benefits, but the pure OTC revenue is still small compared to the whole complex. Anyway, that
componenttext: That's helpful. I guess, my point is EBIT was up 50%. We're still talking 3% of revenue. Again, and I acknowledge the portfolio margining and the future-ization benefits, but the pure OTC revenue is still small compared to the whole complex. Anyway, that was helpful.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one more question. It comes from Ken Hill of Barclays.
componenttext: And one more question. It comes from Ken Hill of Barclays.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to sneak one here, just kind of high level. We've seen some really good organic revenue growth this year. You guys are bringing down the expense guidance here. Does it -- at what point do you think about maybe, perhaps, spending a little bit
componenttext: I just wanted to sneak one here, just kind of high level. We've seen some really good organic revenue growth this year. You guys are bringing down the expense guidance here. Does it -- at what point do you think about maybe, perhaps, spending a little bit more? Do you think the natural constraint there might be around an operating margin well above in the mid-60s? Or -- and how should we think about that longer term if we continue to see this good organic revenue growth against spending levels right now?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, Ken, I'll start and I'll ask John to add. Our willingness and ability to spend is almost entirely dictated by the opportunities that we see. And so there is no stop in spending. If there are opportunities that are worth the investment, we have ne
componenttext: I think, Ken, I'll start and I'll ask John to add. Our willingness and ability to spend is almost entirely dictated by the opportunities that we see. And so there is no stop in spending. If there are opportunities that are worth the investment, we have never hesitated to invest and the -- on a going forward basis, we'll not change that approach.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken. I think when we think about the -- our opportunity set and kind of what we're doing to manage the business, the areas that we're focused on in terms of efficiencies, things like whether it's delayering, whether it's our closing the futures pits
componenttext:
Sure, Ken. I think when we think about the -- our opportunity set and kind of what we're doing to manage the business, the areas that we're focused on in terms of efficiencies, things like whether it's delayering, whether it's our closing the futures pits, whether it's optimizing our data center infrastructure, looking at how we provision and consume professional services, all of those expense management techniques are not in any way, shape or form impacting our ability to grow the business. So those are not growth inhibitors. And we do look at redirecting some of those savings towards investments in our growth opportunity. So you'll see, like for example, whether it's growing our business internationally or whether or not it's investing in our OTC business or whether it's investing in electronifying our options, those opportunities are being able to be funded somewhat through managing our core infrastructure. So we feel good about that. 
In terms of our operating margin, we -- there is no artificial constraint around how high our operating margin can go. I mean, other than 100% for a longer period of time. I think our -- I think the way we look at it is we're managing -- we're pulling levers that we could pull, which is making sure we're running the most efficient engine as we can, and we are also using pricing levers and growing our business through interfacing with our customers. So those are the -- that's what we're focused on. We're not focused necessarily on how high our margins can expand. Now -- and historically, we've been as high as 65% and that was several years ago. So that's the way we've been approaching things.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Thank you, all, for joining us this morning. We are extremely excited about the progress that made this year, and we look forward to seeing you all soon. Thank you very much.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
