componenttext:
I guess my question is going to be broader. It's going to be on the topic of market data. And I'm just trying to get your views as you see your peer or your competitor make a sizable acquisition and with the strategy -- that there is going to be a lot more value placed on market data going forward. 
So I guess, I was just trying to see what your view on that was. Your market data has been performing nicely because of price increases, but just trying to see whether there is an expanse of opportunity or what you think about that?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, this is Gill. I'll start and I'll ask Bryan to address some of the specifics of our market data businesses. If you look at the market data is as we CME, I think we pioneered the acquisition of IP, which we had the opportunity then to actually g
componenttext: Yes, Rich, this is Gill. I'll start and I'll ask Bryan to address some of the specifics of our market data businesses. If you look at the market data is as we CME, I think we pioneered the acquisition of IP, which we had the opportunity then to actually grow with respect to new products and indexes that the S&P, Dow Jones joint venture has. And as part of the business of CME it's 25% before taxes and growing, as John pointed out in his remarks. I will ask Bryan to add a little bit there.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We really worked it consolidating our efforts in terms of our sales effectiveness with market data. And it's enabled us to position ourselves well on a global basis as part of our new client acquisitions or our core products across CME group, market data
componenttext:
We really worked it consolidating our efforts in terms of our sales effectiveness with market data. And it's enabled us to position ourselves well on a global basis as part of our new client acquisitions or our core products across CME group, market data is a big part of that element. So as we get new clients coming in, certainly, part of that is recognized in terms of our market data. So you can expect focus on direct new client, direct sales efforts from that perspective, development and commercialization of data analytics initiatives that we have underway, further growth in terms of our benchmarking services, and then further development of our S&P joint venture. 
So as Gill alluded to, we are intensifying our efforts from that strong relationship.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, you may also have seen that over the course of the last few years as a result of CME group's beginning to clear swaps, we have introduced a lot of analytical tools for our clients with respect to understanding what the impact would margin really req
componenttext: Rich, you may also have seen that over the course of the last few years as a result of CME group's beginning to clear swaps, we have introduced a lot of analytical tools for our clients with respect to understanding what the impact would margin really requirements are going to be as they combine their futures and their swaps portfolios. And so this all requires a lot of tool kits that we have passed onto our client base. And so that even though we don't charge for it. Is becoming a very important element of what our clients need and this has been a trend that has been the case for over the past several years.

componenttext: So I've noticed in some of your marketing a lot more pointed advertising around the Eurodollar, particularly as a comparison to products like Euribor futures, you guys know like people liquidity, some good forward visibility and trading hours as someone overlap with London there. Are there any changes you guys might look to make to the sales force there potentially I guess flush out that opportunity a little bit more and maybe use Eurodollar as a substitute product?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext:
Yes. This is Sean jumping in. So in terms of our Eurodollar futures and our Eurodollar options, absolutely, we have seen an increase interest. We have actually seen very nice jump in the open interest in our Eurodollar options and particularly this year. The big thing to point out is 4 of our 10 largest market makers in 2015 are new. 
So they were not market makers in our Eurodollar options last year, #1 and, #2, they are large market makers in the Euribor complex. So we're definitely penetrating European marketplace in a very substantial way this year in a way that -- In addition to that, one thing I might update folks on in terms of Fed funds. We did see as of yesterday, that meeting, we now have the probability of fed tightening in December well over 40% and the probability according to our Fed funds futures of tightening by March now well over 65%.

But if we were kind of in a scenario where things don't move that much next year, does that make you think about M&A more aggressively or just more tactically?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're always looking at all opportunities as they exist there. And anything that will drive shareholder value for us or makes sense to our business, we will always explore. So it doesn't have to be an exchange necessarily, it has to be a service or a grow
componenttext: We're always looking at all opportunities as they exist there. And anything that will drive shareholder value for us or makes sense to our business, we will always explore. So it doesn't have to be an exchange necessarily, it has to be a service or a growth in initiative around what the client base needs. And so a lot of the analytical tools that we have been providing the marketplace over the last few years as a result, of swap clearing, you can expect us to continue to work in that direction as we start seeing our market and the product that we are rolling out group. I talked a little bit about the 10 year contract a short while ago. I think, if there are any opportunities surrounding those types of things, I did in the commodity space or in the financial space, we will explore, explore them. Currently, as you might know, we have CME venture group that has placed small bets on what I call, emerging trends in the marketplace that might lead to commercial arrangement that we might find with these forms, such as the 1 that we introduced with couple of days ago. So these types of things are always on our radar with a very fair view to what the future might hold for CME group in the space.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is Chris Allen of Evercore.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys have done a very good job in the expense side reducing that can't. I'm just wondering, do you see the further opportunities moving forward? I mean, potentially closing the pits option and for electronic is the obvious 1, but the other area that y
componenttext: You guys have done a very good job in the expense side reducing that can't. I'm just wondering, do you see the further opportunities moving forward? I mean, potentially closing the pits option and for electronic is the obvious 1, but the other area that you guys are focused on improving efficiencies. Where do you think margins could get into a very choppy environment over the course of the year.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is John. We're going through the budgeting and planning process now, I think the entire team has a focus on running the engine as efficiently as possible. So we're looking at, we're constantly looking at how we can optimize our expense base wi
componenttext:
Chris, this is John. We're going through the budgeting and planning process now, I think the entire team has a focus on running the engine as efficiently as possible. So we're looking at, we're constantly looking at how we can optimize our expense base without impacting future growth. And you hit on one of them, which is as we go electronic and as the market takes the option complex electronic that has a potential to offer some cost savings. 
We also are looking at things like consolidating our data centers and continuing that process, optimizing our real estate footprints to make sure that we have, to make sure that we have the optimal space for our employees. We're also looking at utilizing contract services from outside analysis is where we can provision them more cost effectively. As you take look at our account, I would imagine over time, you will see more headcount growing international because as Gill indicated, that's where, that's where our growth is that there is a large amount of our growth coming from overseas. So in terms of our overall margins, we have got the highest margin right now since 2011 with incremental margins above 90%. 
So I think there is no artificial limit in terms of how higher margin can go. In fact, we have hit a high of over 65% in the not so distant pass. So I think, we don't look at it from the perspective of how high we can grow over margin, we look at it in terms of efficiently we're running our expenses, what levers we have to pull to grow the topline, and investing for growth. So that's the way we're thinking about it. And as I mentioned, we're going to be reviewing with our board, our 2016 plan in the coming weeks.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was hoping you could help me kind of characterize the competitive landscape right now in energy trading. Steadily, you guys have a very robust competition with ICE for a number of years, and our NASDAQ coming into the market. How do you see things pl
componenttext: So I was hoping you could help me kind of characterize the competitive landscape right now in energy trading. Steadily, you guys have a very robust competition with ICE for a number of years, and our NASDAQ coming into the market. How do you see things playing out at this point?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Derek. I think that you have seen us do I think a really nice job focusing on what are the natural tailwinds in the energies market right now. The energy market has certainly, started oversupply on the TSI. That said, we are absolutely focuse
componenttext:
Yes, this is Derek. I think that you have seen us do I think a really nice job focusing on what are the natural tailwinds in the energies market right now. The energy market has certainly, started oversupply on the TSI. That said, we are absolutely focused on making sure that we have got a liquid set of poles of cross each of the benchmark products. We have been focused on making sure presence India in the future in the options. Brent is an area that we continue to have about 12% to 13% of. And certainly, the trends we're seeing in the natural gas market, but we don't see necessary huge change in macro trends over the next 12 months, we're continuing to build on our market share that we solidified over the last probably 12 to 15 months there. As it relates to the options business specifically, in TI, we have got 72% of our options in TI trading electronically, now that business is up 50%. 
And options is a real differentiator for us because you look at the magnitude of our business, I think we've got about 165,000 contracts ADV in our TI options, you compare that to your points on the competitive landscape with ICE, they got 50,000 or 60,000 contracts in it. And we know that options volume for perpetuates and strengthens the future franchises contacts so that the area of focus for us. And probably the last thing I would talk about maybe 2 other small pieces, there has been increasing movements on potential in export ban. It went through 1 side. We think there is a broader dialogue that we think is happening. So despite the fact that there is an election next year, the fact that there is part of dialogue in Washington right now we think is very positive, we think it's a good story there. The Chairman testified to that couple of months ago, in D.C. And then finally, if you look at the GSCI re-ratings preliminary announced a couple of weeks ago, we just think that speaks to really what the natural footprint of the ideas in the global landscape. But as I said before, if he can provide a full suite of products to our customers, but there is Brent, clear, even though many crude and DME that's what our customers need, what the customers choose if they want to trade.

componenttext: Just a follow-up on energy. For the power contracts in the third quarter, John, I don't know, if you could outline a pro forma RPC for the energy complex, given the power contracts and so, the run rate going forward on that. And then also, just if you can also talk about some of the new product, especially the Ultra 10-year in the financials, the BTIC in terms of how promising and how quick leasing you think that the ramp-up in near-term?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks Brian. I will take the first one and then Sean can comment on ultra 10-year, that's a definitely product we're excited about. Just with regard to the energy RPC with the small sized, smaller priced power contract, I can understand that the di
componenttext:
Sure, thanks Brian. I will take the first one and then Sean can comment on ultra 10-year, that's a definitely product we're excited about. Just with regard to the energy RPC with the small sized, smaller priced power contract, I can understand that the disconnects. Energy RPC fell about $0.08 compared to last quarter. The RPC again was driven by those smaller sized lower priced contracts, and the bulk of that all occurred in the month of September. 
I think when you take a look at the quarter, the ADV for power contracts this quarter was about 91,000, up from the ADV of about 5000 last quarter. So if you normalized out the RPC for those power contracts, it's about $1.25 on everything else. So that's the impact. I think, what we will do in the future is, we will make sure our monthly volume release that any unusual spikes in the power contract we'll make sure to call that out. I think the important thing is, even with these lower sized, lower-priced contracts, our energy revenue was up 17% this quarter. So we're really pleased with how energy has been performing. And now I turn over to Sean to talk about the TN.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of TN, we are obviously very excited about that. There was an opportunity, participants came to us relative to earlier this year, the bond future jumped what we call the 5-year gap in terms of the maturity spectrum of U.S. Treasury bonds.
componenttext:
Yes. So in terms of TN, we are obviously very excited about that. There was an opportunity, participants came to us relative to earlier this year, the bond future jumped what we call the 5-year gap in terms of the maturity spectrum of U.S. Treasury bonds. 
So with that, the TY future now has achieved to deliver of 7 years, and the bond future has achieved to deliver of 21 year, leaving a very wide gap for additional products. So with customer feedback, we -- extensive customer feedback and excitement, we did decide to -- do that we will launch the end or a 10 year future that achieved to deliver basket of 9.5 to 10 years. So it's very positive feedback. We think it's a product that the marketplace has high demand for. Now obviously, very uncertain as to what the uptake will be, we opportunity for basis trading between that and other products. As you mentioned also and was mentioned during the script, several new equity products, right, so Russell 1000, Russell 1000 growth and value, the FTSE 100, FTSE emerging markets, FTSE China 50 have already been launched related to our agreement with FTSE Russell to be their partner in terms of this products. And then we're very excited in 2017 to launch the absolute thousand. In terms of BTIG or basis trade index close, we're excited about this. This is the first time we're going to be offering that on Globex. Previous it has been a product that has been available in terms of block trading. What this does is, it allows index driven asset managers to trade at exactly or a basis to index close every day, making it extremely efficient for matching their index. So we're very excited about, we had a very positive feedback obviously, there is uncertainty as to how much update you are going to get in the product.

Given the volatility is on a rise and we seem -- we seem to be right on top of rate hike, by the open interest growing faster than it is?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of this is Sean jumping in. The open interest down a little bit, we had a huge, if you look at last year, October of last year was an absolutely phenomenal period of time. Let's recall for example, in rates what happened. Last year, our rates
componenttext:
So in terms of this is Sean jumping in. The open interest down a little bit, we had a huge, if you look at last year, October of last year was an absolutely phenomenal period of time. Let's recall for example, in rates what happened. Last year, our rates complex was up 19% in terms of the ADV and if you look at October of last year, we had a number of driven; we had a surprise easing by the ECB, we had potential for Greek exit, and we had the all-time record on October 15th of last year in terms of the exchange volumes. And that was in part due to the huge open interest at that time. If you recall, interest rates future on day alone we did over 25 million contracts. So we got some very tough comps right now. 
But in addition to that, the helpfulness of our business continues to grow without question. So looking at that in terms of large open interest holders and our investor conference, we have reached an all time record in August. In terms of our FX complex, we also reached an all time record in large open interest holders in August. And the trend in large open interest holders continues to increase and penetration of alternative markets continues to increase. So if you look for example, at our treasury comp is, one thing that we do talk about pretty often is the percentage of treasury futures that trade relative to the cash bond market. Just as a collection in 2013 that was 60%, in 2014, it was 65%, in 2015, we're running at 78%. So all the indications are very healthy marketplace. So I'm focused on the financials. Now I'll turn it over to Derek to talk a bit about commodities.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, I'd probably just add to that. In your decks for the presentation material, if you look at Slide 23, 24 and 25, we've now provided clarity and a view into the large open interest holder on the commodity side of the fence as well. And to the
componenttext: Yes. I think, I'd probably just add to that. In your decks for the presentation material, if you look at Slide 23, 24 and 25, we've now provided clarity and a view into the large open interest holder on the commodity side of the fence as well. And to the point that Sean made we focused not just on the volume, but the quality of participation on our markets as well. So while we're seeing some short-term gyrations largely in the options side, which is fairly typical actually, it's much more volatile in the options OI, than the futures OI, we're appointing new guys to some flat on the commodities open interest holding picture here as well. Particularly on Page 23, on the energy side, if you look at year-on-year, our large open interest is up almost 7.5% year-on-year. So the quality and the number of participants holding significant positions with us is equally important to us at the short-term gyrations in the options side.

componenttext: I just want to quick follow-up on the marketing. So John, you have guided to $10 million down for the year, it looks like will be down even more than that. And just trying to see, what's coming out of marketing this year and is there any bigger impacts as you cut the spend, looks dramatically year-to-year?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Like I mentioned, we are expecting this quarter to be down about 2%, you're going to see the largest increase going from -- going from -- in our marketing and going from Q3 to Q4; it is down about 2% from last year. The bulk of that is coming out of marke
componenttext: Like I mentioned, we are expecting this quarter to be down about 2%, you're going to see the largest increase going from -- going from -- in our marketing and going from Q3 to Q4; it is down about 2% from last year. The bulk of that is coming out of marketing. If you recall, we had some marketing spends and prior years that were really around the MF Global issues as well as some of the kind of the industry issues that were happening. And we reduced that down. We had always anticipated on reducing those costs and you're seeing them reflected now. So I think, we will continue to see an uptick in terms of spend in marketing in the fourth quarter going into next year, but it will be down year-over-year. And it's not necessarily impacting growth at all because these are more kind of overall industry.

I will now turn the call over to Mr. John Peschier. Please begin.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the third quarter, and then we'll open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the third quarter, and then we'll open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.
Before they begin, I will read the safe harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements.
These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements.
More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are available on our website.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us today. We had an outstanding third quarter across the board. We delivered significant topline growth in transaction fees and market data revenue, which, coupled with solid expense control, resulted
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us today. We had an outstanding third quarter across the board. We delivered significant topline growth in transaction fees and market data revenue, which, coupled with solid expense control, resulted in a 21% increase in adjusted earnings per share.
We continue to benefit from revenue strength that is fairly balanced.
Total transaction fee revenue growth for the third quarter was 12%.
Commodity products were 14% higher and financial products were up 10%.
I will go through the highlights of these 2 segments for the quarter, and then, I'll touch on our growth initiatives.
Starting with commodities. All 3 product areas were up double digits in terms of volume. Within energy, average daily volume was up 26%, driven by more than 30% growth in our crude business, while natural gas and refine products have done well, up 9% in total.
Our WTI futures and options volume was up 39% in Q3, while the other major crude offering traded at a competitor was up 70%.
Recently, the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index primarily reweightings were released. The WTI futures are now the largest component and represent 23% of the total index, which clearly reflects our clients choice in risk management tools among our crude oil liquidity pools. Additionally, our WTI options increased by 50% for the quarter.
Turning to ags. We're tracking for a record volume year. During the third quarter, our ag volume was up 20% with continued strength after a record quarter in Q2.
Some highlights include corn, which was up 40% year-over-year, and wheat, which was up 29%. Within metals, precious metals rose 12%, while the smaller base metals grew by 26%.
During the quarter, we continued to roll out innovative new commodities products. We announced a South American Short-Dated Soybean Option contract, offering South American producers a flexible and cost-effective tool to manage new crop price risk.
And on the back of our success in the copper business, which is up 26% in Q3, we continue to expand our base metals product suite.
In addition to launching zinc futures, we are also launching a global physically-delivered lead contract with U.S. and European delivery points as well as new aluminum European premium futures following success with our U.S. Midwest premium futures.
On the European Energy side, we launched a suite of European power contracts to complement the European gas futures that we launch in January, which will be further enhanced by European emissions futures that we plan to launch in the next month. I will touch on some interesting new partnerships in a few minutes.
Moving onto our financial products. We had an impressive quarter in our equity business with volume up 27%, driven by increased volatility.
Equity options growth during the quarter was 32%. During the month of August, we had the 2 higher days ever in our equities option products with both days above 1.9 million contracts.
Within interest rates and FX, we have seen some slowdown in activity as a result of the expectations over Fed move being pushed out several months. We have seen that before and the opportunity remains in front of us.
We continue to innovate and believe, we are well positioned in those products. CME Fed Funds futures volumes have tripled and open interest has doubled this year as the market has used the Fed Funds futures contracts to manage risk in relation to uncertainty of Fed rate hikes.
The CME's FedWatch tool that translate Fed Funds futures prices into probability of rate moves by the FOMC gives a more than 30% chance of a rate move in December and over 50% chance of a rate move by March of 2016.
From a growth perspective, a couple of important points. In early August, we were pleased to announce the licensing deal with FTSE Russell Indexes, and we look forward to driving growth in these products.
We have already launched futures on the Russell 1000, Russell 1000 growth and value, FTSE 100 emerging markets and FTSE China 50 Indexes and other products.
We will be rolling out the FTSE emerging markets, the FTSE developed Europe in 2016, and most importantly, the Russell 2000 in 2017. In addition, on November 16, we plan to launch S&P dividend index futures as well as introducing the so-called Basis Trade Index at close or BTIC functionality to the S&P 500, NASDAQ and Dow Jones Index futures.
Within interest rates, last week, we announced plans to launch the Ultra 10-year Treasury Note futures and options contract, which I alluded to last quarter. This contract provides hedging and spreading opportunities at the true 10-year point of the treasury yield curve.
Market participants approached us in the first half of this year and suggested that we look at a futures contract that can provide deep liquidity and capital and margin efficiencies of the treasury futures complex to the highly traded 10-year point on the treasury yield curve.
CME conducted an extensive market valuation process of 3 potential contract designs. We found great enthusiasm, interest and deeply held views on the design and usefulness from market participants. The design announcement for the new Ultra 10-year futures has elicited a significant positive feedback from our customers.
Looking at our global business. We had the best quarter ever in terms of volume and percentage of total volume from outside the U.S.
The total electronic average daily volume for the quarter of 3.2 million contracts was up 15% from the prior year.
In addition, the total electronic volume traded from outside of the U.S. exceeded 25% for the first time and revenue from outside of the U.S. represented 32% of the total. Our interest rate business has been particularly strong outside the U.S. as electronic revenue has grown from 31% in Q3 last year to 37% this quarter.
We continue to establish global partnerships, particularly in Asia over the last few months. We announced an exclusive license arrangement with Rim Intel -- Intelligence, a leading provider of pricing data in Japan, to develop and clear energy derivatives based on their LNG data. Secondly, we signed an MOU with MCX, India's leading commodity exchange related to product development, market allegation and the licensing agreement for rupee-denominated oil and gas contracts based on NYMEX prices.
We have made 3 noteworthy announcements with Chinese entities. We announced an index development and product licensing agreement with China Securities Index Company for commodity index development. We signed an agreement with CFETS, China's largest marketplace for interest rate and foreign exchange products related to joint development and innovation of offshore renminbi and related products. As part of the agreement, CFETS will help facilitate China Interbank market participants to trade CME Group's products. And finally, last week, we signed an MOU with China Construction Bank to offer offshore Chinese RMB futures contract with physical delivery in London for the first time, which will be offered by CME Europe.
We believe our cooperative efforts will continue to unlock opportunities for our shareholders as we continue to grow our customer base and volume around the world.
Turning to our options business. As you know, we have invested in system enhancements, new products, and investor education, which are driving significant usage of over diverse suit of option products.
Q3 options volume reached a record level of 2.9 million contracts per day. We also saw the highest percentage of this business trading electronically, which reached 55% electronic during the quarter. One of the key drivers of our continued electronic options success is on investment in enabling more complex options spread to trade on Globex.
In Q3, we saw a record 45% of all option spreads trade electronically versus just 10% in 2010. And volume in the world's largest major options contracts, our Eurodollar options traded on Globex, jumped by more than 60% to a record 200,000 contracts per day in Q3 and reached 21% electronic versus 14% a year ago.
In summary, we continue to deliver strong results, but more importantly, we are intensely focused on running the business as efficiently as we can while laying the foundation for future growth in the years to come.
I'm going to turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. CME had a strong quarter, another great job by the team on both the revenue and expense side with revenue up 12% and expenses basically flat. Our adjusted operating margin of 62.7% was the highest level we have
componenttext:
Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. CME had a strong quarter, another great job by the team on both the revenue and expense side with revenue up 12% and expenses basically flat. Our adjusted operating margin of 62.7% was the highest level we have seen since 2011. Finally, our adjusted EPS grew 21% during the quarter compared to the prior year driven by organic growth.
I'll start with some revenue details. The rate per contract for the third quarter was $0.759, down from $0.777 last quarter, driven primarily by a product shift from ags to equities, volume discounts and a drop in the energy RPC as a result of the contract mix. In September, within energy, we saw a significant increase in our small size power contracts, which accounted for 8% of the energy volume for that month or a 161,000 contracts per day.
During the second quarter, the power contracts accounted for less than 1 half of 1% of the volume, and for Q3, that jumped up to 5% at an average of $0.06 per contract.
Cleared swaps revenue totaled $16.3 million for the quarter. We captured $166 per IRS-cleared trade, higher than we've seen in prior quarters due to our customer mix. We cleared approximately 1,370 trades per day in Q3.
Market data revenue of $99.5 million was up 13% versus Q3 last year, driven primarily by the elimination of our fee waiver program, which we have discussed the last few quarters. This came in slightly below our guidance, and we would expect it to dip slightly in Q4.
Adjusted operating expenses for the third quarter were $317 million, down from last year. We remained extremely focused on driving efficiency throughout the organization and eliminating redundancy to continue to improve agility and customer and market responsiveness. At the end of the quarter, we had 2,525 employees, down 5% from 3 months ago, driven by our futures pit closures in July and staff reductions in August. Our headcount is down 11% from the same quarter last year. Stock-based compensation cost came in below our normal run rate, primarily due to higher forfeitures on expenses we previously recognized.
After some variability in our stock-based compensation in the last 2 quarters, we expect to revert to a run rate of approximately $50 million per quarter. Modest fluctuations may result in future periods due to some changes in expectations regarding achievement of performance shared targets.
Our compensation ratio year-to-date is running at an industry leading 16.1%, down from 17.1% in 2014 and 17.4% in 2013. During the quarter, it came in at 15.4%.
Looking at the nonoperating income and expense line, our ownership in the S&P, Dow Jones joint venture drove the $26.6 million in net earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries, which was up 33% from the prior year.
We remain pleased with the investment we made in the index business, while also assuring, we continue to offer the world's leading index futures products on CME.
Turning to taxes, the effective rate for the quarter was 36.3%. I expect the fourth quarter to be approximately 37% for a full year tax rate of 36.6%.
And now to the balance sheet. At the end of the third quarter, we had $1.61 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities. That is approximately $910 million above our $700 million minimum cash target. During the third quarter, capital expenditures net of leasehold improvement allowances was $30 million and year-to-date CapEx is totaled $85 million. We expect full year 2015 CapEx to be backend loaded in Q4 and should come in lower than we expected at approximately $125 million.
For the full year expenses, we initially guided to $1.31 billion, which we reduced by $10 million last quarter, and I'm going to reduce that by another $5 million to $1.295 billion. This includes absorbing a $12 million increase in license fees so far this year based on volume growth. The guidance would result in a 2% expense reduction in Q4 compared to the prior year on an adjusted basis.
As we mention at this time every year, we have a large amount of marketing and customer-related spend in the fourth quarter that will drive the sequential increase from Q3.
Finally, we communicated and adjusted 2016 transaction fee schedule across all 6 product areas to our customers last week. We expect the transaction fee revenue to increase approximately 2%, assuming the same volume levels and product mix next year.
In summary, the third quarter of 2015 once again, demonstrated the power of CME Group's business model. Broad-based volume growth from our diverse product set and our disciplined expense management drove adjusted EPS up more than 20%, continuing our growth in the first half of the year.
We also continue to generate a significant amount of excess cash, which we plan to return to our shareholders.
With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. Given the number of analysts who cover us, we ask that you limit yourself to 1 question so we can get to everyone. Please feel free to get back into the queue if you have any further questions. Thank you.

Just wanted to think, next year, what's the expense outlook, particularly what you mentioned just on like the equity compensation normalizing?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Again, this is John. In terms of the market data, as you can imagine, forecasting attrition is not an exact science. And revenue came in slightly lower than we had guided to, and we'd anticipate it being slightly lower, again, in the fourth
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. Again, this is John. In terms of the market data, as you can imagine, forecasting attrition is not an exact science. And revenue came in slightly lower than we had guided to, and we'd anticipate it being slightly lower, again, in the fourth quarter. We are keeping a strong eye on it as we go into next year. As you know, those that were grandfathered will now be paying the full -- the full freight amount, which is approximately double what they are paying today. We don't have any guidance on that as yet. We are working with our clients to make sure that we keep that -- any attrition down to as low as possible. In terms of expenses, we're going through the budgeting process now. As you can imagine, we are focused strongly on expenses and will be giving guidance in the -- during the first quarter -- I'm sorry, end of the year conference call in January. In terms of expenses, we're down about 2% based on our guidance in the fourth quarter. Again, we're focused on expenses going into next year, and we'll be making sure that we're optimizing the entire expense base during the budgeting process. As it relates to stock-based compensation, what you saw this quarter was an adjustment because the grant date and the vesting date for the stock awards occurs annually in September, and that -- the forfeiture rates are updated at this time, and because of the actions we've taken over the last few years, we had to adjust it to reflect the reduced number of employees. We're anticipating going back to approximately a $15 million run rate on stock-based compensation, but there will be some variability in it going into next year because of the proportion of performance-related stock awards will cause some fluctuation because they adjust, both based on our performance as well as performance of the S&P 500 or a group of peer companies.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just -- the stock base was 11 and you're saying it's just going to 15. So I just want to make sure I had that number right.
componenttext: Okay. And just -- the stock base was 11 and you're saying it's just going to 15. So I just want to make sure I had that number right.

componenttext: Yes. It's been trending about 15. We had an adjustment last quarter because of performance, and in this quarter because of the reduced number of employees. So it will go back to approximately $15 million run rate.

componenttext: I guess my question is going to be broader. It's going to be on the topic of market data. Your market data has been performing nicely because of price increases, but just trying to see whether there is an expansive opportunity or what you think about that?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, this is Gill. I'll start, and then I'll ask Bryan to address some of the specifics of our market data businesses. If you look at the market data business with CME, I think we pioneered the acquisition of IP, which we had the opportunity then to actu
componenttext: Rich, this is Gill. I'll start, and then I'll ask Bryan to address some of the specifics of our market data businesses. If you look at the market data business with CME, I think we pioneered the acquisition of IP, which we had the opportunity then to actually grow with respect to new products and indexes that the S&P, Dow Jones joint venture has. And as part of the business of CME, it's 25% before taxes and growing, as John pointed out in his remarks. I will ask Bryan to add a little bit here.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We really worked at consolidating our efforts in terms of our sales effectiveness with market data. And it's enabled us to position ourselves well on a global basis as part of our new client acquisition or our core products across CME group, market data i
componenttext: We really worked at consolidating our efforts in terms of our sales effectiveness with market data. And it's enabled us to position ourselves well on a global basis as part of our new client acquisition or our core products across CME group, market data is a big part of that element. So as we get new clients coming in, certainly, part of that is recognized in terms of our market data. So you can expect focus on direct new client, direct sales efforts from that perspective, development and commercialization of data analytics initiatives that we have underway, further growth in terms of our benchmarking services and then further development of our S&P joint venture. So as Gill alluded to, we're intensifying our efforts from that strong relationship.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rich, you may also have seen that over the course of the last few years as a result of CME group's beginning to clear swaps, we have introduced a lot of analytical tools for our clients with respect to understanding what the impact of margin really -- req
componenttext: Rich, you may also have seen that over the course of the last few years as a result of CME group's beginning to clear swaps, we have introduced a lot of analytical tools for our clients with respect to understanding what the impact of margin really -- requirements are going to be as they combine their futures and their swaps portfolios. And so this all requires a lot of toolkits that we have passed onto our client base. And so that forms part and parcel, even though we don't charge for it. it's becoming a very important element of what our clients need, and this has been a trend that has been the case for the past several years.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I've noticed in some of your marketing a lot more pointed advertising around the Eurodollar, particularly as a comparison to products like Euribor futures, you guys know like deeper liquidity, some good forward visibility and trading hours as someone o
componenttext: So I've noticed in some of your marketing a lot more pointed advertising around the Eurodollar, particularly as a comparison to products like Euribor futures, you guys know like deeper liquidity, some good forward visibility and trading hours as someone overlap with London there. Has that generated much interest there from participants in the market of historically traded products like Euribor? And are there any changes you guys might look to make to the sales force there to potentially, I guess, flush out that opportunity a little bit more and maybe use Eurodollar as a substitute product?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Sean jumping in. So in terms of our Eurodollar futures and our Eurodollar options, absolutely, we have seen an increased interest. We've actually seen a very nice jump in the open interest in our Eurodollar options and in particular this y
componenttext: Yes. So this is Sean jumping in. So in terms of our Eurodollar futures and our Eurodollar options, absolutely, we have seen an increased interest. We've actually seen a very nice jump in the open interest in our Eurodollar options and in particular this year. The big thing to point out is 4 of our 10 largest market makers in 2015 are new. So they were not market makers in our Eurodollar options last year, #1 and, #2, they are large market makers in the Euribor complex. So we're definitely penetrating European marketplace in a very substantial way this year, in a way that -- in addition to that, one thing I might update folks on in terms of Fed Funds. We did see, as of yesterday, that meeting. And now the probability of Fed tightening in December well over 40% and the probability according to our Fed Funds futures of tightening by March now well over 65%.

componenttext: My question is for Gill, and it's around kind of your views on M&A and how that might evolve if you just stay with some of the Fed funds futures outlook? And just kind of update us on your thoughts at this point?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dan, we're always looking at all opportunities as they exist there. And anything that will drive shareholder value for us or makes sense to our business, we will always explore. So it doesn't have to be an exchange necessarily, it has to be a service or a
componenttext: Dan, we're always looking at all opportunities as they exist there. And anything that will drive shareholder value for us or makes sense to our business, we will always explore. So it doesn't have to be an exchange necessarily, it has to be a service or a growth initiative around what the client base needs, right? And so a lot of the analytical tools that we have been providing the marketplace over the last few years as a result of swap clearing, you can expect us to continue to work in that direction as we start seeing our market and the products that we are rolling out grow. I talked a little bit about the 10-year contract a short while ago. I think if there are any opportunities surrounding those types of things, either in the commodity space or in the financial space, we will explore them. Currently, as you might know, we have a CME venture group that has placed small bets on, what I call, emerging trends in the marketplace that might lead to commercial arrangement that we might find with these firms, such as the one that we introduced with [indiscernible] a couple of days ago. So these types of things are always on our radar with a very fair view to what the future might hold for CME group in this space.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Chris Allen of Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question is Chris Allen of Evercore.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You guys have done a very good job in the expense side reducing the headcount. I'm just wondering, do you see further opportunities moving forward? I mean, potentially closing the pits further if option [indiscernible] electronic is the obvious one, but a
componenttext: You guys have done a very good job in the expense side reducing the headcount. I'm just wondering, do you see further opportunities moving forward? I mean, potentially closing the pits further if option [indiscernible] electronic is the obvious one, but are there other area that you guys are focused on improving efficiency? And where do you think margins could get to in a very tough environment over the course of the year?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is John. We're going through the budgeting and planning process now. And I think the entire team has a focus on running the engine as efficiently as possible. So we're looking at -- we're constantly looking at how we can optimize our expense b
componenttext: Chris, this is John. We're going through the budgeting and planning process now. And I think the entire team has a focus on running the engine as efficiently as possible. So we're looking at -- we're constantly looking at how we can optimize our expense base without impacting future growth. And you hit on one of them, which is, as we go electronic and as the market takes the option complex electronic, that has a potential to offer some cost savings. We also are looking at things like consolidating our data centers and continuing that process, optimizing our real estate footprints to make sure that we have -- to make sure that we have the optimal space for our employees. We're also looking at utilizing contract services from outside the United States where we can provision them more cost-effectively. As you take look at our headcount, I would imagine, over time, you will see more headcount growing internationally because, as Gill indicated, that's where our growth is. There is a large amount of our growth coming from overseas. So in terms of our overall margins, we have got the highest margin right now since 2011 with incremental margins above 90%. So I think there is no artificial limiter in terms of how high our margin can go. In fact, we have hit a high of over 65% in the not so distant past. So I think, we don't look at it from the perspective of how high we can grow our margin, we look at it in terms of efficiently we're running our expenses, what levers we have to pull to grow the topline and investing for growth. So that's the way we're thinking about it. And as I mentioned, we're going to be reviewing with our board our 2016 plan in the coming weeks.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Patrick O'Shaughnessy of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Patrick O'Shaughnessy of Raymond James.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was hoping you could help me kind of characterize the competitive landscape right now in energy trading. Certainly, you guys have a very robust competition with ICE for a number of years, and now you have NASDAQ coming into the market. How do you see
componenttext: So I was hoping you could help me kind of characterize the competitive landscape right now in energy trading. Certainly, you guys have a very robust competition with ICE for a number of years, and now you have NASDAQ coming into the market. How do you see things playing out at this point?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Derek. I think that you have seen us do, I think, a really nice job focusing on what are the natural tailwinds in the energies market right now. The energy market has, certainly, started oversupply on the TI side. That said, we're absolutely
componenttext: Yes, this is Derek. I think that you have seen us do, I think, a really nice job focusing on what are the natural tailwinds in the energies market right now. The energy market has, certainly, started oversupply on the TI side. That said, we're absolutely focused on making sure that we've got a liquid set of pools across each of the benchmark products. We have been focused on making sure presence in TI in the future is in the options, Brent is an area that we continue to have that 12%, 13% of. And certainly, the trends we're seeing in the natural gas market, while we don't see necessary huge change in macro trends over the next 12 months, we're continuing to build on our market share that we solidified over the last probably 12 to 15 months there. As it relates to the options business, specifically in TI, we got 72% of our options in TI trading electronically now, that business is up 50%. And options is a real differentiator for us because if you look at the magnitude of our business, I think we've got about 165,000 contracts ADV in our TI options. You compare that to your points on the competitive landscape with ICE, they got 50,000 or 60,000 contracts in. And we know that options volume perpetuates and strengthens the futures franchise. So that's an area of focus for us. And probably the last thing I'd talk about, maybe 2 other small pieces, there has been increasing movements on potential lifting of the export ban. It went through one side. We think there is a broader dialogue that, we think, is happening. So despite the fact that there is an election next year, the fact that there is part of dialogue in Washington right now, we think, is very positive, we think there's a good story there. The Chairman actually testified to that a couple of months ago in D.C. And then finally, if you look at the GSCI re-ratings preliminary announced a couple of weeks ago, we just think that speaks to really what the natural footprint of TI is in the global landscape. But as I said before, if we can provide a full suite of products to our customers, whether it's is Brent, TI, even the Omani crude in DME, that's -- it's what our customers need. We'll let the customers choose what they want to trade.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on energy. For the power contracts in the third quarter, John, I don't know, if you could outline a pro forma RPC for the energy complex given the power contracts and the run rate going forward on that? And then also, just if you can also
componenttext: Just a follow-up on energy. For the power contracts in the third quarter, John, I don't know, if you could outline a pro forma RPC for the energy complex given the power contracts and the run rate going forward on that? And then also, just if you can also talk about some of the new products, especially the Ultra 10-year in the financials, BTIC in terms of how promising and how quickly you think that can ramp-up in near-term?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Brian. I'll take the first one and then maybe Sean can comment on ultra 10-year, that's definitely a product we're excited about. Just with regard to the energy RPC with the small sized, smaller-priced power contract, I can understand the di
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Brian. I'll take the first one and then maybe Sean can comment on ultra 10-year, that's definitely a product we're excited about. Just with regard to the energy RPC with the small sized, smaller-priced power contract, I can understand the disconnects. Energy RPC fell about $0.08 compared to last quarter. The lower RPC, again, was driven by those smaller-sized, lower-priced contracts, and the bulk of that all occurred in the month of September. I think when you take a look at the quarter, the ADV for power contracts this quarter was about 91,000, up from the ADV of about 5000 last quarter. So if you normalize out the RPC for those power contracts, it's about $1.25 on everything else. So that's the impact. I think, what we will do in the future is we will make sure on our monthly volume release that any unusual spikes in the power contract, we'll make sure to call that out. I think the important thing is even with these lower-sized, lower-priced contracts, our energy revenue was up 17% this quarter. So we're really pleased with how energy has been performing. And I'll turn it over to Sean to talk about the TN.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of the TN, we are, obviously, very excited about that. There was an opportunity, participants came to us relative to earlier this year, the bond future jumped, what we call, the 5-year gap in terms of the maturity spectrum of U.S. Treasur
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of the TN, we are, obviously, very excited about that. There was an opportunity, participants came to us relative to earlier this year, the bond future jumped, what we call, the 5-year gap in terms of the maturity spectrum of U.S. Treasury bonds. So with that, the TY future now has achieved to deliver of 7 years, and the bond future has achieved to deliver of 21 year, leaving a very wide gap for additional products. So with customer feedback, we -- extensive customer feedback and excitement, we did decide to -- that we will launch a TN or a 10-year future that will have achieves to deliver a basket of 9.5 to 10 years. So it has very positive feedback. We think it's a product that the marketplace has high demand for. Now, obviously, very uncertain as to what the uptake will be, will we significant opportunity for basis trading between that and other products. As you mentioned also and as was mentioned during the script, several new equity products, right, so Russell 1000, Russell 1000 growth and value, the FTSE 100, FTSE emerging markets, FTSE China 50, have already been launched related to our agreement with FTSE Russell to be their partner in terms of these products. And then we're very excited in 2017 to launch the Russell 2000. In terms of BTIC or basis trade index close, we're excited about this. This is the first time we're going to be offering that on Globex. Previously, it has been a product that has been available in terms of block trading. What this does is it allows index-driven asset managers to trade at exactly or at a basis to index close every day, making it extremely efficient for matching their index. So we're very excited about it. We've had very positive feedback. But obviously, there is uncertainty as to how much uptick you are going to get in the new product.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Great. And the 10-year notice launch later this quarter?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: I guess, just on the RPC guidance of 2% increase year-on-year for 2016 with the pricing changes going to affect, John, can you just give us some more guidance as to where we should expect the most significant impact? Is it right to think about the ags and rates of products to be most significantly impacted, or what line should we expect to come through?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Kyle. As we have mentioned, we announced an overall 2% price increase. I mean, we looked at -- we look comprehensively at our price levels, volume tiers and incentive plans and strategically adjusted them. And as we mentioned, we took action ac
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Kyle. As we have mentioned, we announced an overall 2% price increase. I mean, we looked at -- we look comprehensively at our price levels, volume tiers and incentive plans and strategically adjusted them. And as we mentioned, we took action across all of our asset classes. So rates and energies where the highest impacted and FX and metals were the least impacted.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is Amanda Yao of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question is Amanda Yao of JPMorgan.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Amanda, and I'm filling in for Ken Worthington. In terms of open interest, futures' open interest is flat and options' open interest is down year-over-year. Given the volatility is on a rise, and we see -- we seem to be right on top of a rate hike
componenttext: This is Amanda, and I'm filling in for Ken Worthington. In terms of open interest, futures' open interest is flat and options' open interest is down year-over-year. Given the volatility is on a rise, and we see -- we seem to be right on top of a rate hike, why isn't open interest growing faster than it is?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of -- this is Sean jumping in. The open interest is down a little bit. We had a huge -- if you look at last year, October of last year, right, was an absolutely phenomenal period of time. Let's recall for example, in rates what happened. Last
componenttext: So in terms of -- this is Sean jumping in. The open interest is down a little bit. We had a huge -- if you look at last year, October of last year, right, was an absolutely phenomenal period of time. Let's recall for example, in rates what happened. Last year, our rates complex was up 19% in terms of the ADV. And if you look at October of last year, we had a number of events; we had a surprise easing by the ECB; we had the potential for Greek exit; and we had the all-time record on October 15 of last year in terms of the exchange volumes. And that was, in part, due to the huge open interest at that time. If you recall, interest rate futures on that day alone, we did over 25 million contracts. So we've got some very tough comps right now. But in addition to that, the helpfulness of our business continues to grow without question. So looking at that in terms of large open interest holders and our interest rate complex, we reached an all-time record in August. In terms of our FX complex, we also reached an all-time record in large open interest holders in August. And the trends in larger open interest holders continues to increase and penetration of alternative markets continues to increase. So if you look, for example, at our treasury complex, one of the things that we do talk about pretty often is the percentage of treasury futures that trade relative to the cash bond market. Just as a recollection in 2013, that was 60%; in 2014, it was 65%; in 2015, we're running at 78%. So all the indications are that it's a very healthy marketplace. So I'm focused on the financials. Now I'll turn it over to Derek to talk a bit about commodities.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, I'd probably just add to that. In your decks for the presentation material, if you look at Slides 23, 24 and 25, we've now provided clarity and a view into the large open interest holder on the commodity side of the fence as well. And to the
componenttext: Yes. I think, I'd probably just add to that. In your decks for the presentation material, if you look at Slides 23, 24 and 25, we've now provided clarity and a view into the large open interest holder on the commodity side of the fence as well. And to the point that Sean made, we focus not just on the volume, but the quality of participation in our markets as well. So while we're seeing some short-term gyrations, largely in the options side, which is fairly typical actually, it's much more volatile in the options OI than the futures OI. We're pointing you guys to some clarity on the commodities open interest holding picture here as well. Particularly on Page 23, on the energy side, if you look year-on-year, our large open interest holding is up almost 7.5% year-on-year. So the quality and the number of participants holding significant positions with us is equally important to us as the short-term gyrations in the options side.

componenttext: I just wanted to quick follow-up on the marketing. So John, you guided to $10 million down for the year, it looks like will be down even more than that. And just trying to see, what's coming out of marketing this year and is there any bigger impacts as you cut the spend, it's looks dramatically year-to-year?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Like I mentioned, we are expecting this quarter to be down about 2%, you're going to see the largest increase going from -- in our marketing line, going from Q3 to Q4, and is down about 2% from last year. The bulk of that is coming out of marketing. And i
componenttext: Like I mentioned, we are expecting this quarter to be down about 2%, you're going to see the largest increase going from -- in our marketing line, going from Q3 to Q4, and is down about 2% from last year. The bulk of that is coming out of marketing. And if you recall, we had some marketing spends in prior years that were really around the MF Global issues as well as some of the kind of the industry issues that were happening. And we reduced that down. We had always anticipated on reducing those costs, and you're seeing them reflected now. So I think, we'll continue to see an uptick in terms of spend in marketing in the fourth quarter going into next year, but it will be down year-over-year. And it's not necessarily impacting growth at all because these were more kind of overall industry campaign based.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
